user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete:
```c
int32 OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    osal_id_t final_id;

    /* Clear the OSAL ID if successful - this returns the record to the pool */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        final_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    }
    else
    {
        /* this restores the original ID */
        final_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* Either way we must unlock the object type */
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id);

    /* Give event callback to the application */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_RESOURCE_DELETED, token->obj_id, NULL);
    }

    return operation_status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED ((osal_id_t){0})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no occurrences of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. Specifically: - No use of __attribute__, __asm, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... })gcc extension, nested functions, or other known compiler extensions. - The macro OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED uses a compound literal ((osal_id_t){0}), which is standard C (since C99), not a compiler extension. - All typedefs shown (int32 mapped to int32_t, osal_id_t to uint32) rely on standard fixed-width integer types from stdint.h, not extensions. - Function definitions, pointer dereferences (token->obj_id), and taking the address of a local ( &final_id ) are standard C constructs. Therefore there are no code fragments that, based on the provided source, require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions). If you want, I can re-check against a specific compiler’s documentation if you provide which compiler and its list of documented extensions.
